comments.body: There should be a short-circuit return here, when oldConfig and the new one are equal.
Adding a short-circuit return here would simply mean checking every field so see whether they changed, which I already do. In term of performance and logic, there would be no difference.
Yes. Except for this case, which is worth checking too.

I'd add `See [AnimatedCrossFade.defaultLayoutBuilder] for an example implementation'.

I also wonder if the keys should be uniquely generated `GlobalKey`s instead, thus allowing more interesting layouts than those based on multiple children. In fact, I wonder if we would need to pass the keys here at all if they are `GlobalKey`s?

We want to avoid using global keys if at all possible. They're expensive.

You can always convert a LocalKey to a GlobalKey if you really need a global key on the receiving end.

~~added your suggested text~~

Actually, i've just put in some sample code instead.
This is still not needed: the `ExcludeFocus` is a no-op when `excluding` is false.

I get an error in testing when I remove ExcludeFocus, but I don't know why. Can you please help me?
<details>
<summary>error</summary>

00:04 +5 -1: AnimatedCrossFade preserves widget state [E]                                          
  Test failed. See exception logs above.
  The test description was: AnimatedCrossFade preserves widget state
  
00:04 +5 -1: AnimatedCrossFade switches off TickerMode and semantics on faded out widget           
══╡ EXCEPTION CAUGHT BY FLUTTER TEST FRAMEWORK ╞════════════════════════════════════════════════════
The following TestFailure object was thrown running a test:
  Expected: <true>
  Actual: <false>

When the exception was thrown, this was the stack:
#4      main.<anonymous closure> (file:///Users/zuvola/Documents/Projects/etc/flutter/packages/flutter/test/widgets/animated_cross_fade_test.dart:317:5)

</details>

Ahh, I see. I'm wrong: you actually do need the `ExcludeFocus` with `excluding` set to false here, because otherwise the change in the widget hierarchy causes the children's state to be rebuilt, which is undesirable. It's true that it is a no-op when it comes to focus state, but not with respect to the widget tree topology.
OK, I understand. Thank you for the detailed explanation.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +358,362 @@      child: ExcludeSemantics(
        excluding: false, // Always publish semantics for the widget that's fading in.
        child: ExcludeFocus(
          excluding: false,
          child: FadeTransition(
